title: RL31809
content: In November 2003, Congress combined remaining appropriations bills into an omnibus bill (H.R. 2673). A conference report (H.Rept. 108-401) was issued before Thanksgiving. The House approved the report on December 8, 2003, and the Senate passed it on January 22, 2004. The President signed The Consolidated Appropriations Act (P.L. 108-199) on January 23, 2004. In February 2003, the Bush Administration submitted its budget for fiscal year 2004. Hearings were held in March and April by the CJS appropriations subcommittees in the House and Senate. The House passed the CJS appropriations bill (H.R. 2799) on July 23, 2003, and the Senate introduced its CJS bill (S. 1585). The Senate Appropriations Committee introduced the CJS bill (S. 1585) on September 5, 2003, with a total budget of roughly $41.22 billion. The House bill (H.R. 2799) contained a similar budget of $41.23 billion. The Senate bill provided approximately $40.37 billion. The Consolidated Appropriations Act allocated a total of $41 billion for various departments. The CJS appropriations bill typically includes five titles to fund departments and agencies, such as Justice, Commerce, The Judiciary, State, and Independent Agencies. The Administration's request for FY2003 was $44.019 billion, with the Senate passing an omnibus spending package for CJS appropriations during the 108th Congress. The FY2003 CJS appropriations totaled $44.940 billion in the Senate and $44.353 billion in the House. The consolidated FY2003 appropriation package (P.L. 108-7) was passed by the 108th Congress on February 20, 2003. An emergency supplemental appropriations bill (P.L. 108-11) provided additional funding to selected entities within CJS. The total FY2003 appropriation for CJS was approximately $40.498 billion after adjustments. Funding trends for major agencies in CJS from FY1998-FY2003 showed increases in budgets for the Department of Justice, Commerce, Judiciary, and State. The Justice Department's budget decreased by $4.7 billion in FY2003 compared to FY2002. The Commerce Department budget steadily increased over five years, with a significant rise in FY2000 due to the census. The State Department and Judiciary Branch also saw funding increases from FY1998 to FY2003, with the State Department receiving the greatest nominal increase of about $3.608 billion. The CJS bill appropriations have increased steadily before FY2003, with some departments receiving significant funding boosts post-9/11. Funding for the bill decreased in FY2003 due to transfers to the Department of Homeland Security. Key issues for FY2004 CJS appropriations include the Department of Justice's request for additional funds for counterterrorism efforts and proposed realignment of assistance grants. The FY2003 funding for state and local law enforcement assistance programs is over $1 billion. Key issues include limitations on the use of fees by the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office, federal support for industrial technology development programs at the National Institute of Standards and Technology, and the broadcast-ownership cap for national audience. The Judiciary is considering a funding increase to meet mandatory expenses and operate at FY2003 staffing levels. The Judiciary is considering funding increases to meet mandatory expenses and operate at FY2003 staffing levels. This includes discussions on increasing the hourly rate of pay for court-appointed attorneys, cost-of-living salary increases for federal judges and justices, visa issuance policies, and Homeland Security proposals. Additionally, there are plans for expanded public diplomacy activities, increased hiring of experts, and improved information technology within the Department of Justice. The Department of Justice agencies and offices include United States Attorneys who prosecute criminal offenses, represent the federal government, and collect fines. The United States Marshals Service provides security for the judiciary, executes warrants, and apprehends fugitives. The FBI investigates federal criminal law violations and terrorism threats. The DEA investigates federal drug law violations and coordinates with other agencies. The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms focuses on regulating controlled substances activities. The Department of Justice oversees intelligence-gathering activities with foreign governments, enforces federal laws related to alcohol, tobacco, firearms, and explosives, manages the federal prison system, coordinates various justice programs, and focuses on defending the nation against terrorist attacks. The Department of Justice works with the Department of Homeland Security to prevent terrorist attacks and transfer enforcement programs. They collaborate with the intelligence community to enhance intelligence sharing and reorganize the FBI to counter terrorism effectively. Federal involvement in crime control has increased over the years through various crime control bills. Since 1984, Congress has passed multiple crime control bills, increasing federal involvement in crime control. The Government Performance and Results Act (GPRA) mandated the Department of Justice to create a strategic plan, including goals such as protecting the US from terrorism, enforcing federal laws, and administering immigration laws fairly. The Department's FY2003 performance plan focuses on various goals to ensure the safety and security of American society. The Department of Justice's FY2004 request included $19 billion, with a focus on counterterrorism, DNA initiatives, and efficiency measures to offset proposed increases and eliminate grant programs. The FY2004 Department of Justice budget included program reductions, offsets, and the elimination of several grant programs, such as COPS hiring and overtime program, Juvenile Justice Accountability Block Grant, and State Criminal Alien Assistance Program. The Administration proposed to replace Local Law Enforcement Block Grants and Byrne Grants with a Justice Assistance Grant program, with $600 million allocated. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2004 provided DOJ with $20 billion for FY2004, including funding for various COPS programs. The Administration's FY2004 request for Justice programs included $1.378 billion for General Administration, with $810 million allocated for the Detention Trustee account. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2004 provided $1.331 billion for general administration, $47 million less than the Administration's request. The FY2004 request for Justice programs included $1.378 billion for General Administration and $810 million for the Detention Trustee account. The Consolidated Appropriations Act provided $1.331 billion for general administration, $47 million less than the request. The Detention Trustee's Office received $814 million, with the Senate bill proposing $850 million and the House bill $810 million. The Office of the Inspector General received $62 million in the FY2004 request. The Administration's FY2004 request included $62 million for the OIG, a $10 million increase from FY2003. The Consolidated Appropriations Act provided $61 million for the OIG, same as the Senate bill. The House-passed bill would have provided $56 million. For the U.S. Parole Commission, the FY2004 request was $11.1 million, a $631 thousand increase from FY2003. The Consolidated Appropriations Act provided $10.6 million. The Senate-reported bill would have provided $10.8 million, while the House-passed bill would have provided $10.6 million. The Legal Activities account for FY2004 included nearly $3.2 billion in funding, with the Consolidated Appropriations Act providing $3.094 billion. The general legal activities account funds various departmental divisions and the Solicitor General's supervision of proceedings before the Supreme Court. The Administration's request for this account was $665 million, with the Consolidated Appropriations Act providing nearly $621 million. The Consolidated Appropriations Act for FY2004 provides nearly $621 million for the Legal Activities account, which includes funding for the Radiation Exposure Compensation Act program. The U.S. Attorneys Office received $1.526 billion in funding, $31 million less than the Administration's request, while the U.S. Marshals Service budget was not specified. The House-passed bill would have provided $1.526 billion for U.S. Attorneys and $734 million for the U.S. Marshals Service in FY2004. The Senate-reported bill would have allocated $628 million for the Marshals Service. The House-passed bill also included $41 million for U.S. Marshals-related activities under the Community Oriented Policing Services account. The FY2004 request for Independent Counsel, U.S. Trustee Fund, and Asset Forfeiture program was $257 million, $43 million less than the Consolidated Appropriations Act funding of $214 million. The Senate bill proposed $290 million, including $66 million for office automation. The House-passed bill would have provided $209 million for legal activities, while the Interagency Law Enforcement account reimburses agencies for participating in the OCDETF program to disrupt major narcotics trafficking organizations. Various federal agencies participate in OCDETF, including the DEA, FBI, IRS, ATF, Coast Guard, Marshals Service, and others. Additionally, DHS's Customs and Border Protection and Immigration and Customs Enforcement may also participate. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2004 provides funding for interagency drug enforcement and the Federal Bureau of Investigation for FY2004. The Act allocates nearly $557 million for interagency law enforcement, with $415 million targeting major narcotics trafficking and money laundering operations. The FBI receives $4.64 billion to focus on counterterrorism efforts. The Appropriations Act for FY2004 allocates funding for the FBI, including $62 million for the Foreign Terrorist Tracking Task Force, $11.2 million for construction, and $490 million for counterintelligence/national security. The request also includes budget increases for various activities such as counterterrorism, cybercrime, and information technology improvements. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 transferred certain FBI units to the Department of Homeland Security. The NDPO and DEST were absorbed by OJP's Office of Domestic Preparedness, while NIPC was transferred to DHS's Information Analysis and Infrastructure Protection Directorate with $51 million and 307 positions. The DEA is tasked with reducing drug supply and abuse and received $1.6 billion for FY2004. The DEA received $1.6 billion for salaries and expenses in FY2004, with an additional $557 million for interagency drug enforcement. The ATF was provided with $836 million in the Consolidated Appropriations Act for FY2004. The ATF received $836 million in funding for FY2004, which was slightly higher than the amounts proposed in the Senate and House bills. The budget included $852 million for ATF, with increases for new initiatives like the Youth Crime Gun Interdiction Initiative and the Safe Explosives Act implementation. The ATF's spending limitations were also modified to restrict certain activities related to firearm transfer records. The Federal Prison System received $4.862 billion in funding for FY2004, an increase of nearly $418 million over the previous year. This budget would house an average daily population of 143,197 sentenced offenders in federal institutions and 28,043 in contract facilities. The Administration requested $4.493 billion for the Federal Prison System, which was $369 million less than the Consolidated Appropriations Act. The Consolidated Appropriations Act provides $398 million for prison facility construction, modernization, and repair in FY2004. The Senate-reported bill proposed $346 million, the House-passed bill $203 million. The Administration's request included funds for new facilities, counterterrorism projects, contract confinement, and a drug treatment program. Budget increases were to be offset by savings from efficiencies and rescinded construction funding. The Office of Justice Programs manages various justice-related agencies and grant programs. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2004 provides $3.095 billion for the Office of Justice Programs and related offices. Funding differences for FY2003 and FY2004 are due to various factors including the transfer of the Office of Domestic Preparedness to DHS and changes in funding for programs like State Criminal Alien Assistance and COPS hiring. The Consolidated Appropriations Act for FY2004 provides funding for various justice programs, including a proposal to consolidate grants and reduce funding compared to FY2003. The OJP budget traditionally includes accounts for Justice Assistance, State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance, Weed and Seed crime prevention, Community Oriented Policing Services, Juvenile Justice programs, and Public Safety Officers Benefits. The Act also allocates funds for Violence Against Women Act grant programs separately. The Consolidated Appropriations Act for FY2004 provides funding for various justice programs, including Justice Assistance, State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance, Weed and Seed, Community Oriented Policing Services, Juvenile Justice Assistance, VAWA programs, and Public Safety Officer Benefits. The Senate and House bills proposed different funding amounts for these programs. The Justice Assistance account funds OJP bureaus and offices, including the National Institute of Justice and Bureau of Justice Statistics. Congress appropriated nearly $200 million for FY2003, with the Administration requesting $2.125 billion for FY2004. The proposed realignment includes program categories like Counterterrorism Research, Criminal Justice System Improvement, Juvenile Justice System Strengthening, and Services for Victims of Crime. COPS programs would be separate, with only 7 programs funded in the COPS account. Other COPS programs would be replaced or eliminated, with some funded under the Justice Assistance account. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, the Senate-reported bill, and the House-passed bill do not align with the Administration's proposed budget realignment of OJP programs. State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance funding amounts differ between the three bills, with the Administration requesting less for FY2004 due to the exclusion of the State Criminal Alien Assistance Program and the proposed consolidation of the Byrne and Local Law Enforcement Assistance grant programs. The Consolidated Appropriations Act for FY2004 provides varying funding amounts for different programs compared to the Senate-reported and House-passed bills. Funding for SCAAP is set at $300 million, Local Law Enforcement Block Grants at $225 million, Byrne grants at $659 million, and Violence Against Women Act grants at $388 million. The Weed and Seed program aims to reduce crime in specific neighborhoods through prevention and human service programs. The Consolidated Appropriations Act for FY2004 provides funding for various programs, including the Weed and Seed program and the Community Oriented Policing Services (COPS) program. The COPS program receives $756.3 million in funding, with $120 million allocated for hiring. The Senate-reported bill and House-passed bill propose different funding amounts for COPS, with the Senate bill including $200 million for hiring and overtime. The House bill does not allocate funding for COPS hiring. The House bill did not include funding for COPS hiring and overtime, as the Administration's request also did not include funding for this program. The Consolidated Appropriations Act provided $30 million for the National Criminal History Improvement Program, $110 million for the DNA/Crime Lab Improvement program, and assistance under the Juvenile Justice Assistance programs to improve juvenile justice and corrections. OJP provides assistance for juvenile justice and corrections programs, with funding reauthorized by Congress. The Consolidated Appropriations Act allocated $353 million for Juvenile Justice Assistance programs, with varying amounts proposed by different entities. The Public Safety Officers Benefit Program offers death benefits. The Public Safety Officers Benefit Program provides death benefits to survivors of officers who die in the line of duty and disability benefits to those injured. Funding for the program in FY2004 was $52 million, slightly higher than the Administration's request. The Senate report highlighted funding for the Foreign Terrorist Tracking Task Force, which would be a stand-alone account within the Department of Justice budget. The Senate bill would provide the FBI with $415 million for interagency crime and drug enforcement, and $552 million for interagency law enforcement support. The Homeland Security Act transferred the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives to the DOJ. The FY2004 budget request includes a large increase for the Office for Justice Programs grant programs. The House-passed bill includes funding for Violence Against Women Act programs under the Office of Justice Programs, as well as appropriations for Operation Seahawk and the Local Law Enforcement Block Grant Program in San Juan, Puerto Rico. Additionally, the Protect Act was passed into law in 2003, and the Law Enforcement Partnership to Combat Terrorism Act aimed to amend the COPS program for hiring and enforcement efforts. The Terrorism Act introduced a bill to amend the COPS program for hiring and training intelligence officers to improve coordination of counterterrorism efforts. The CLEAN-UP of Methamphetamines Act aimed to increase enforcement and prosecution of methamphetamine offenses. Another bill sought to include Assistant United States Attorneys in the definition of law enforcement officer for retirement purposes. H.R. 2387 (Strickland)/ S. 1194 (Dewine) and H.R. 2943 (Hooley) aim to improve collaboration and resources in criminal and juvenile justice systems. S. 679 (Biden) reauthorizes appropriations for COPS programs. S. 798 (Hatch) focuses on the Sex Offender Apprehension Act of 2003. S. 798 (Hatch) Sex Offender Apprehension Act of 2003 would amend the COPS program to assist states in enforcing laws requiring convicted sex offenders to register their addresses with law enforcement agencies. Introduced on April 7, 2003. The Department of Commerce, established in 1913, has various responsibilities including promoting American business, improving technological competitiveness, encouraging economic development, fostering environmental stewardship, and compiling statistical information on the U.S. economy and population through its agencies like the Economic Development Administration (EDA). The Department of Commerce carries out missions through agencies like the Economic Development Administration (EDA), Minority Business Development Agency (MBDA), Bureau of the Census, Economic and Statistical Analysis Programs, International Trade Administration (ITA), Bureau of Industry and Security, and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) to promote economic development, support minority businesses, collect economic data, analyze economic trends, facilitate international trade, enforce export control laws, and provide scientific expertise for marine and air safety. The Department of Commerce utilizes various agencies to promote economic development, support minority businesses, collect economic data, facilitate international trade, and provide scientific expertise for marine and air safety. Additionally, it oversees agencies like the Patent and Trademark Office, Technology Administration, National Institute of Standards and Technology, and National Telecommunications and Information Administration to manage patents, advocate technology policies, assist industry in technology development, and advise on communications policy. The Administration requests $5.814 billion for Title II in FY2004 appropriations, including the Commerce Department. The President's FY2004 request for the International Trade Administration was $382.1 million, with the House passing $395.1 million. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $372.1 million. The Omnibus Appropriations Act enacted the House figure of $395.1 million. The International Trade Administration (ITA) received $395.1 million in funding from the Omnibus Appropriations Act, along with an expectation of $13 million in fee collection. ITA provides export promotion services, ensures compliance with trade agreements, administers trade remedies, and supports trade negotiations. It is divided into four policy units and an Executive and Administrative Directorate, with a staff of 2,550. The Trade Development Unit (TD) was allocated $46.7 million by the House, renamed as the Manufacturing and Services Unit (MSU) to focus on promoting U.S. industry competitiveness and expansion. The Trade Promotion Unit, including the Advocacy Center and the Trade Information Center, received funding in the President's FY2004 budget. The House funded textile initiatives at 2003 levels, while the Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $69 million for certain initiatives. The Market Access and Compliance Unit (MAC) received $37.4 million in funding, with the House directing the establishment of an Office of Enforcement within the Unit. P.L.108-199 enacted the House figure of $46.7 million and its reorganization proposal. The House appropriated $68.2 million for the Import Administration Unit (IA) and directed its reorganization. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $46.6 million for IA, including funds for monitoring import data and customs flows. P.L. 108-99 enacted the House amount and reorganization proposal. The Commercial Service Unit requested $204.5 million in funding. The U.S. and Foreign Commercial Service, now known as the Trade Promotion Unit (TPU), received an appropriation of $217 million from the House. The TPU was directed to take over trade promotion functions from the current TD Unit and establish Business Information Centers in the Middle East and China. The House also instructed the agency to create American Trading Centers in China. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $202 million for the Commercial Service and supported the Appalachian-Turkish Trade Project. The USTR, responsible for U.S. international trade policies, had 209 FTEs in FY2003. The U.S. international trade policies were under the responsibility of the USTR, which had 209 FTEs in FY2003. The President's FY2004 request for the USTR was $37 million, with the House appropriating $42 million. The request included funding for negotiating additional free trade agreements with various countries. The House expressed concerns about USTR's responsiveness to complaints from small and medium-sized businesses regarding trade enforcement with China. Additionally, the House allocated $2 million for monitoring and enforcing trade commitments with China, while cautioning against using U.S. Treasury funds to resolve trade disputes. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommends adopting the President's request of $37 million for the USTR. They also direct negotiations at the WTO to recognize members' rights to distribute funds from antidumping and countervailing duties. Provisions of the Byrd Amendment were deemed inconsistent with WTO Agreements in 2003. The enacted legislation prohibits using funds to negotiate trade agreements involving temporary entry of foreign workers. The ITC advises the President and Congress on trade matters. The International Trade Commission (ITC) requested a budget of $58.3 million for FY2004, which was approved by Congress. The increase in funding was intended for a pay raise, information technology projects, and improving trade information. The Bureau of Industry and Security (BIS) requested $78.2 million for FY2004, with Congress appropriating $74.7 million in FY2003. The Bureau of Industry and Security (BIS) received $74.7 million in FY2003, with $68.2 million enacted through the Omnibus Appropriations Act of 2004. BIS administers export controls on dual-use goods and technology, facilitates cooperation with other nations on export control policy, and monitors the U.S. defense industrial base. The agency had 459 full-time employees in FY2003. The House appropriated $68.2 million, with funds allocated for export administration, licensing activities, enforcement, and activities related to the Chemical Weapons Convention. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $73 million for similar activities. The Bureau of Industry and Security (BIS) received $74.7 million in FY2003, with $68.2 million enacted through the Omnibus Appropriations Act of 2004. BIS sought to create a new Office of Technology Evaluation to identify sensitive new technologies for inclusion on the Commerce Control List (CCL) and conduct reviews of items on the CCL. This initiative was proposed in response to criticism from the GAO. The House and Senate did not provide funds for this new office. The Economic Development Administration had requested a total appropriation of $364.4 million for FY2004, with $331 million for Economic Development Assistance Programs (EDAP). The Economic Development Administration received a total appropriation of $318.7 million, with $288.1 million for Economic Development Assistance Programs (EDAP) and $30.6 million for Salaries and Expenses (S&E). Specific allocations include $202.3 million for Public Works and Economic Development, $40.9 million for Economic Adjustment Assistance, $24 million for planning, $8.4 million for technical assistance, $12 million for trade adjustment assistance, and $500,000 for research. The Administration had requested $349.9 million for FY2003, with $317.2 million for EDAP. Hearings were held on the Administration's proposal for reauthorizing EDA. The House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee adopted a modified version of the Administration's five-year reauthorization bill. The bill also incorporates a modified version of the Administration's new performance incentive program for grantees. The award program focuses on grantees completing projects on schedule, exceeding job creation goals, and leveraging private sector capital. For the Minority Business Development Agency in FY2004, Congress passed $28.9 million, with the Administration requesting $29.49 million. The Economic and Statistical Analysis programs requested $84.76 million for FY2004, with the House bill providing $75 million and the Senate bill matching the Administration's request. The BEA's timely and accurate statistical reports are crucial for policymakers, industry, and consumers. The conference agreement allocated $75 million for the Bureau of the Census in FY2004, with programmatic increases in recent years for more accurate economic data. President Bush requested $662 million, including $220.9 million for salaries and expenses and $441.1 million for periodic programs. The House approved the request, directing the Bureau to prioritize core activities and supporting a simplified census design for 2010. The House and Senate recommended funding for the Bureau of the Census in FY2004, with a total of $630.9 million allocated. This included $255.2 million for the 2010 census planning. The Senate Appropriations Committee noted available recoveries of $12.2 million from prior year obligations. The committee directed the Bureau to provide a report on reimbursements received for work performed for other federal agencies and organizations by May 1, 2004. The National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) is the executive branch's advisory office on telecommunications and information technology issues. Its budget includes Salaries and Expenses, the Technology Opportunity Program (TOP), and the Public Telecommunications Facilities, Planning and Construction (PTFPC) program. NTIA aims to provide greater access to telecommunications services, support U.S. market openings, advise on international negotiations, fund research grants, and assist non-profit organizations with digital transmission. The Bush Administration's FY2004 budget for NTIA includes $21.4 million, with $18.6 million for Salaries and Expenses. The Technology Opportunity Program (TOP) receives zero funding, as it has achieved its objectives. The Public Telecommunications Facilities, Planning and Construction (PTFPC) program is allocated $2.5 million to close out activities, with public broadcast transmission and digital conversion transitioning to the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. The conference report allocates $14.6 million for NTIA's FY2004 budget. The conference report provides $51.6 million for NTIA's FY2004 budget, with allocations for Salaries and Expenses, TOP, and PTFPC. The USPTO is funded by user fees, with a proposed budget authority of $1.404 billion for FY2004. H.R. 2799 recommended $1.239 billion in budget authority for the USPTO. The FY2004 budget for the USPTO was provided $1.222 billion in budget authority, derived from fees collected in FY2004, which was 3% more than FY2003 but $282 million less than anticipated fees. In FY2003, the USPTO had a budget authority of $1.182 billion, with $1.015 billion from offsetting collections and $167 million from prior year fees. The US Patent and Trademark Office has faced limitations in utilizing fees collected since 1990, sparking controversy. Opponents argue for immediate financing of agency operations, while proponents believe current methods help balance the budget. Funding was allocated for ongoing commitments and centers lacking federal support for six years. The FY2004 budget for the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) saw a 30% reduction, affecting the Advanced Technology Program and Manufacturing Extension Partnership. Funding was allocated for ongoing commitments and centers lacking federal support for six years. The initial House-passed bill provided $460.1 million for NIST, but it was later incorporated into the FY2004 Omnibus Appropriations Act, resulting in a total funding of $628.1 million, 12% below the FY2003 appropriation but 26% above the President's budget request. The FY2004 budget for NIST saw a 30% reduction, affecting the Advanced Technology Program and Manufacturing Extension Partnership. The STRS account will receive $344.4 million, a 3.6% decrease from FY2003. Manufacturing extension is financed at $39.6 million, a 63% reduction from the current fiscal year. ATP is funded at $179.2 million, almost 7 times the amount recommended by the Administration. Construction will receive $64.9 million. S. 1585 would have funded NIST at $835.2 million for FY2004, 18% above FY2003. The Committee Report recommended allocating $50 million of the ATP budget for homeland security projects. The Advanced Technology Program provides seed financing for the development of generic technologies with broad applications, facing criticism as corporate welfare but defended for assisting businesses in technology development. The Advanced Technology Program, crucial for industrial competitiveness, faced funding challenges in FY2004. The Manufacturing Extension Partnership also saw decreased federal funding. However, appropriations for NOAA Facilities were significantly less than requested, with obligations transferred to a different NOAA account. The Judiciary budget in FY2003, including supplemental appropriations, was $4.92 billion, with more than 10 separate accounts funded. The President must transmit the judicial branch's proposed budget to Congress unchanged, as per statute. The Judiciary budget for FY2003 totaled $4.92 billion, with over 10 separate accounts funded. The Supreme Court's budget consists of two accounts, covering salary, operational expenses, and building care. Justices testify before appropriations subcommittees, with the Supreme Court's budget representing a small portion of the Judiciary's overall funding. The total appropriations for the Supreme Court in FY2003 were $88.3 million, 1.8% of the Judiciary's total appropriation. The rest of the budget funds the lower federal courts and related judicial services, with the Salaries and Expenses account for the U.S. Courts of Appeals being the largest among the lower court accounts. The Salaries and Expenses account for the U.S. Courts of Appeals and District Courts covers salaries of various judicial personnel, including circuit and district judges, retired justices, U.S. Court of Federal Claims, bankruptcy judges, and more. Other accounts for lower courts include Defender Services, Fees of Jurors, U.S. Court of International Trade, Administrative Office of the U.S. Courts, Federal Judicial Center, and U.S. Sentencing Commission. The Judiciary budget request is presented to House and Senate appropriations subcommittees after review. Construction of federal courthouses is also not funded within the Judiciary's budget. For FY2004, the Judiciary requested a 10.3% increase to $5.43 billion in total funding, excluding funding for courthouse construction. The Judiciary's FY2004 budget request included increases for various accounts, with the majority allocated to the Salaries and Expenses account. The requested increase was attributed to maintaining current operations, pay and benefit adjustments, inflationary adjustments, and other needs such as high-profile terrorist trials and bankruptcy filings. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist requested a higher total appropriation for the Judiciary in FY2004 due to concerns that the funding levels proposed by the Senate Appropriations Committee could lead to significant staffing reductions in probation and pretrial services.
